ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: for what crime she was killed,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: For what crime she was put to death;
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: for what offence was she killed?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: such as, "For what crime were they murdered?"
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: Upon what sin was she killed for.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: For what sin was she killed
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: For what sin she was killed,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: for what sin she was slain,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: For what sin she was slain,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: for what sin she was killed,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: For what sin she was slain.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: for what sin she was killed.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: For what crime she was killed;
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: For what sin she was killed?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: for what crime she was slain,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: For what crime was she killed?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: For what sin she was killed
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [81:9] for what sin she was slain (sa’alat, ‘asks’: a variant reading has su’ilat, ‘[she] is asked’, narrating the address directed to her, to which she then responds by saying, ‘I was slain without [having committed] any sin’);
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (For what sin she was slain) for what sin did you kill me; it is also said that this means: when the one who 734 killed her is asked: for what sin did you kill her,
